Steam gave me the notification that publisher Jagex was going to have a free weekend (at the time of writing) for two of their games: Ace of Spades, a Minecraft lookalike that plays like a military shooter, and Carnage Racing, a kart racer.

The free weekend hadn't started yet, but Carnage Racing piqued my interest. I like racing games, and I seem to recall maybe being vaguely excited for Carnage Racing years ago when I saw it on Gametrailers? I wasn't sure.

But outside of the Free Weekend it was on sale for $2.50, so rather than wait like a sensible human being, I bought it sight unseen.

And, boy, I learned a lesson today.

The game itself feels like it fell off of the iPhone in the worst way possible. The music is super uninspired, the sounds are limp and wimpy, the art is kind of questionable (what is up with that dude's proportions?), the cars are sluggish, and the weapons don't feel good (not only that, but you are totally, 100% defenseless in first place).

On top of that, the game informs you that you can use any USB gamepad to play the game, but does not offer any control customization options. reviewText:
Picture yourself in one of those gigantic racing game booths that you find at arcades - rubber steering wheel, gum on the seat and all. This is that, but in your house, with better music, with multiplayer mode, more cars, more achievements, and more fun. I've had it for two days, and I've already played it for 10 hours.

Carnage Racing is unpredictable and fun. That's the bottom line. You can pick up weapons throughout the race course, and you never know whether somebody will slow you down, bomb you, portal up next to you... Or maybe you'll do the same to them. It truly is carnage. I also appreciate the pun in the title, which is a pretty big plus. As expected from Jagex, always slipping little jokes into their games.

There are a few downsides, of course. The campaign is pretty easy. There aren't any instances when you're on a hairpin's breadth, trying to beat an AI. It only took me about five hours to get all the achievements and fully upgrade a few cars (with some EPIC paint jobs, I might add.) The AIs are a bit stupid, often crashing into you at the start, but after that things straighten out and get fun. The maps are a bit blurry. I'm often lagging when I enter a new game zone. 'Game zones' - the entire game is made up of maybe seven different map sections, lasting thirty seconds or so each. Each map is a little boring, because it's just a new combination of a zone or two. That's about it, though. I've read about other people having glitches, but I haven't, so I don't care.

Looking past some of the downsides, once again, this game is fun. The cars handle well, the weapons are pretty epic, and what it loses in refined content, it makes up for in raw imagination. As someone who's played a lot of Jagex sidescrollers and other games - Arcanists, Armies of Gieleinor, Runescape, you name it - this fits among the rest of them quite well. It's up to you whether you like that or not. I do!

Thanks, Jagex!

reviewText:
I bought this game on the recent free weekend, i bought it a 4-pack and game the extra copies to 3 friends of mine. It was really cheap, yes, but not worth it. I would like to start this review by saying this was not only an mobile game once, but also a facebook game. Yeah, you heard it right. Even the developers know this was a bad idea.
The game started fun, i played some time with my friends and we were having fun, the problem was, that the game is completely unbalanced. Think of Mario Kart, now focus on the unfair things, like the freakin Blue Shell, now think that if you play more than everybody you will have an oportunity to upgrade the blue shell in a way that it multiplies and hits every other player. Now forget all of that, because this game is even more unfair. You have an item that simply teleports you to the nearest player in front of you no matter how far you are, and you can upgrade it after grinding some money in the game. When you do upgrade this teleport to the maximum (like i did), you can teleport to 3 players ahead of you. So if you are playing it with 2-3 friends (like me), you will always appear right next to the first place. This game do not reward your skills, it rewards your luck. Also, if you play more than your friends, you can upgrade all your items to the max and make the game impossible for the ones who have less time or are busy playing actual well-made games.
But that is not the worst part, when playing multiplayer (even though the game was repetitive as hell and had a lack of maps) i actually had some kind of fun. What really made me come here to write this negative review was the singleplayer.
After my friends left the game i decided to play the campaing alone so i could unlock the other cars (no, you can't freakin unlock them multiplayer). The AI wasn't a big deal, the challengs were not that hard. The problem is that when i got through a part of the game, completed all challenges in all the missions i played, and when i was trying to restart a race the game crashed. Ok, normal. I opened it again and... my save was gone! Simple as that, all the upgrades i had, all my stars, everything was gone.
Maybe you are thinking i only wrote this review because i was angry, but the game is actually really unbalanced and repetitive. Also, i have all my reasons to be angry, i lost my frekin save.

Pros:
+Kind of fun multiplayer.
+Ok graphics.
+Good sensation when exploding someone.

Cons:
-Repetitive.
-Unbalanced.
-Rewarding the wrong players.
-Unsafe save file.
-SinglePlayer sucks.
-Steam port of a Mobile-Facebook game.

Conclusion
Don't buy this game, if you want a arena racing game to play with friends, go buy Post Apocalyptic Mayhem or Zero Gear.

Originally designed as a Facebook Online browser game, the game has progressed to the point of ios versions and Steam only from then on to enter a early grave.

The game and racing mechanics and strategy needed to win here by juggling weapon usage and upgrades, portal jumping and skilled driving is quite good. Developers rarely ever offer customer support, and it seems to be an abandoned game, promising no new content in the way of maps, cars or any other dlc.

I was a big fan of Jag Ex only to find that their delivering of development promises ran out of petrol way too quick. In a nutshell the way this game has been left decomposing and there will soon be nothing left of it other than a fossil fuel. Having said that its funny as hell when you see some one about to enter a portal gate and so you zap them of their energy and instead see them drive straight into a brickwall at high speeds. Oh the memories and the fun times you have given me. RIP Carnage Racing. I've said my prayers and lay a boquet of oil sludge on your tombstone.

reviewText:
Carnage Racing is one of those titles that sounds great on paper. It is a multiplayer focused kart racing game featuring lots of weapons, big jumps, stunts and a unique mechanic in racing games – portals. Yes this is probably the only racing game where you can warp around the track. These can be used to take shortcuts and reach places other drivers cannot.

There is a short single player championship against somewhat dodgy AI cars and each race has a set number of challenges to complete. These range from simply finishing in first place, performing jumps, blasting a set number of cars etc. Unfortunately the intelligence of the other drivers is...well...they are stupid! Carnage Racing has the sort of drivers that are single minded and will just do whatever they want and ignore you, usually just trying to drive straight through your vehicle.

Controls aren't that great either. When playing with a controller the left stick is used for both steering and those stunts which sounds OK, but just doesn't work in practice. For example a double press left or right causes you car to flip over, but sometimes you need to straighten up for a landing (you can steer in mid air) and when you try to do this you flip over without meaning to as if there's some invisible gremlin taking control. The stunt controls are also quite unresponsive so even if you really want to flip or spin you don't and end up just hitting left or right waiting for it to do something.

Having said that when it all comes together the game can be great fun. The problem is that these moments are too few and far between. Add to this a number of bugs and glitches and many faults in the game design and what you get is an annoying, frustrating, unfair mess of a game.

The single player is very easy though which goes some way to make up for the problems. In fact the challenge does not come from the actual racing, but from trying to complete those challenges. Some of which are easier to get once you upgrade your vehicles or buy a new one.

Taking the game online does make things better. Human opponents play much better the the computer and when you have a full roster you can see what the developers were trying to achieve. Having said that there are too few cars and tracks meaning that you will see everything the game has to offer in a short space of time.

If you can live with it's problems and have a few friends who like to play then there is a semi-decent game buried here, if not then you are probably better of spending your hard earned elsewhere.

reviewText:
Mediocre Arcade Racer but still quite amusing.
This racing game tries to mix a bit of Portal with Mariokart. You can fill up a meter which allows you to create portals at certain points that allow you to take a bit of a shortcut by dropping you further along the track or by putting you on a different path of the track all together. It actually makes for quite an interesting and suprisingly fluid gameplay a you can jump through the track quite quickly.

Next to that you have your missiles, bombs and other equipment to deal with your opponents including another type of portal device that will pull you straight behind an opponent ahead of you. This means that unlike, say MarioKart, there is no need for handicap racing where the lead racer slows down and the ones behind speed up simply because there are enough ways to catch up in otherways.

The game has a comprehensive tutorial which is worth going through, especially the tricks section as performing tricks allows you to load up your meter a bit faster.
Online gameplay seems fairly smooth allowing you to jump in to games easily enough and personally I haven't ran in to many big issues other than ending up stuck after a weird portal jump but that has only happened once in over 20 odd hours of play.

So far the good bits, now on to the bad.

The sound is rubbish. I've heard better car sounds from an RC toy car, it is that bad. Weapon sounds are pretty mediocre as well and the music is the same loop again and again and it is uninspired to say the least. Turn off the music and just play your own is my advice. Though it isn't intrusive, it just becomes elevator music.

The tracks are limited there are realistically only 5 tracks namely beach, town, lava, hangar and temple. However with the portal technique they stitch them together like frankenstein's monster and to be fair it does work quite well, but not well enough as all the tracks start to literally blend together.

The handling of the cars also leaves much to be desired. The turning circle is awful, while you are racing this isn't an issue you can take the turns of the track at full speed without slowing down anywhere, but if you get knocked around due to flying explosives or other, and you end up facing the wrong way it is infuriatingly difficult to turn around. The easiest way I have found is to roll with it and drive against the flow. The game will then eventually turn you around on its own.
It is also rather inconsistent. Sometimes the game will rapidly put you back upright on the track if you find yourself upside down and othertimes you end up waiting for ages before the game decides you are allowed to play once more.

The cars are rather uninspired, not a lot of variety, and if you have gone through the trouble of unlocking the speedsters you will have an advantage over the other two types negating the need to drive anything else for any reason.

Furthermore once you have upgraded your car with all the bells and whistles, there is no use for any of the cash that just piles up. Yes you can do a bit of pain customisation but it is lacklustre and costs pennies while you have nearly a million accrued.

All in all the game has a nice idea, and had it been given a bit more polish and a bit more of everything it could have been very good. Instead it is solidly mediocre and in my opinion isn't worth the asking price, there are far better racers out there

However that is not to say I'm not having fun with this game. I am, quite a lot infact. racing online or with friends is incredibly good fun, the races only last a few minutes and can be quite a frantic affair so if you see it cheaply (and I mean very cheaply) and are in the mood for some low effort, high entertainment then I do recommend it.

reviewText:
There are quite few things that are working against this game.
First of all, graphics feel like it is an iOS port. Also, controls are sometimes not very precise, since when doing tricks in few cases game does not register what kind of trick I want to make. AI is not really good, but I guess that it is here only to teach you the tracks and to let you go online.
But progress in the game is rather slow. Unlocking cars and making moolah (or whatever the money is called) takes very long time. Some people would not probably mind grinding - thus they will have huge advantages online.

But even on this free weekend online experience is not very good. More often than not person who is hosting the game would go offline, so half a minute is spent while the game decides who is the next host. And loading maps takes too much time - considering that models are really simple and maps don't have many details going on.

What is good is that even from the last place in the race with some luck you can come on top - if you happen to pick right powerups and use right shortcuts with phasing. Nice and innovative concept. There is some replay value in finding optimal route on each map.

Alas, it is not enough for me to keep playing this game. I will be uninstalling it.

Oh, yes, and I had more fun with Asphalt 7 than with this game.

Nice little time waster for one or two hours, but quickly becomes boring. 5/10

reviewText:
Carnage Racing is a fun racer. It's not amazing and you shouldn't expect it to be for under two dollars with the four pack (current sale price we got it for). However, it's worth the money. Play it with some friends and have a blast. Many laughs to be had. The people reviewing this saying the Microsoft 360 controller does not work are NOT correct. Or maybe it is THEIR controller that doesn't work correctly. I can confirm that my Xbox One controller works perfectly and I played with four friends who were all using Xbox 360 controllers (both wired and wireless). The only thing that doesn't work is you have to use a mouse to navigate through the menus. Can that be annoying? Sure. But we're already on the PC anyway. It's right there in front of you. It's really not that big of a deal.

If you have friends to play it with give it a try. To each is their own but I honestly enjoy it and I know the four I played with enjoyed themselves as well. 8 player multiplayer is nice if you play on a regular basis with larger groups. Normally we have to have a person sit out or rotate in since most co-op games are 2-4 players so having up to 8 online is a nice touch. I did notice we had a few issues hosting games. Not everyone had to option to choose a level to host when they went into multiplayer so we had to switch off. We did not try to open any ports however so I do not know if that would have fixed the issue for us. We had one race out of 20 something where two people disconnected but other than that everything went smoothly.

Phasing is a neat addition and managing your meter or having it drained by an opponent right before going through a portal and slamming into a wall creates some hilarious moments. The trick system seems a bit hit or miss between choosing front/back flips or spins/rolls. Either way, there is fun to be had. I would not grab this at full price but for a couple dollars, go for it. I have also played the single player and enjoy it as well. I like the challenge system to earn stars to unlock more vehicles as it adds to the replay value. The levels are fun but I do admit a few of them are similar or the same track raced backwards. Thanks for taking the time to read this. Have a good one!
